entry.title: Dynamically Making a Field Read-Only in SAP RAP
entry.content:
Introduction 

 Making a field read-only or non-editable dependent on the value of another field is a frequent requirement. This blog post will explain how to use the RAP model to accomplish this.

The scenario we'll cover is making the VBTYP field read-only based on the value of the AUART  field. 

Setting Up the RAP Application 

Before implementing the dynamic behavior, we need a basic RAP application structure. 

  1. Database Table
@EndUserText.label : 'Data base Table for sales order'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table zdemo_dt_so {
  key vbeln : vbeln_va not null;
  erdat     : erdat;
  ernam     : ernam;
  vbtyp     : vbtypl;
  auart     : auart;
}

  2 . Interface View

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Interface view for sales order'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define root view entity ZDEMO_I_SO as select from zdemo_dt_so
{
    key vbeln as Vbeln,
    erdat as Erdat,
    ernam as Ernam,
    vbtyp as Vbtyp,
    auart as Auart
}

 3 . Projection View

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Projection view for Sales order'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
define root view entity ZDEMO_P_SO as projection on ZDEMO_I_SO
{
    key Vbeln,
    Erdat,
    Ernam,
    Vbtyp,
    Auart
}

  4 . Behavior Definition 

managed implementation in class zbp_demo_i_so unique;
strict ( 2 );
define behavior for ZDEMO_I_SO //alias <alias_name>
persistent table zdemo_dt_so
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
//etag master <field_name>
{
field (features : instance ) Vbtyp ;
validation vbtyp_valid on save { field Auart , Vbtyp ; }
  create;
  update;
  delete;
}
projection;
strict ( 2 );
define behavior for ZDEMO_P_SO //alias <alias_name>
{
  use create;
  use update;
  use delete;
}

  5 .Service Definition and Binding

@EndUserText.label: 'Service def SO'
define service ZDEMO_P_SO {
  expose ZDEMO_P_SO;
}

Once you click on preview you can see the application and create a record

Implementing Dynamic Feature Control 

Our goal is to make the  ,VBTYP field read-only if the AUART field has a specific value, like 'KA'.

For Achieving this scenario first we need to Define a Dynamic feature control for the field 'VBTYP' 

The logic for making the field read-only  presents in the  

get_instance_features method of your behavior implementation class. This method is automatically created  by the RAP framework. Here's the code you'll need to write: 

 METHOD get_instance_features.

  READ ENTITIES OF ZDEMO_I_SO IN LOCAL MODE
   ENTITY zdemo_i_so FIELDS ( Vbeln  Auart )
   WITH CORRESPONDING #( keys )
   RESULT data(lt_result).
        LOOP AT lt_result INTO data(ls_result).
        if ls_result-Auart = 'KA'.
        result = VALUE #(
        (
        %tky = ls_result-%tky
        %features-%field-Vbtyp = if_abap_behv=>fc-f-read_only
        ) ).
        ELSE.
        result = VALUE #(
        (
        %tky = ls_result-%tky
        %features-%field-Vbtyp = if_abap_behv=>fc-f-unrestricted
        ) ).
        ENDIF.
        ENDLOOP.

  ENDMETHOD.

After implementing the logic, activate your behavior implementation class. Now, when you refresh your  application, the changes will be applied  

In your application, you can create a few records with different  

AUART values, such as 'KA' and 'OR'. When you try to edit the record where  

AUART is 'KA', you will notice that the VBTYP field is grayed out and you are unable to change its value. However, if you edit a record where 

AUART is 'OR', the VBTYP field will remain editable, allowing you to change its value freely.

This demonstrates how the field's behavior is dynamically controlled. 

Conclusion  :  

The blog post effectively demonstrates how to dynamically make a field read-only within the SAP RAP.  The core method involves using dynamic feature control.

entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Minimum UX you need for SAP Business AI and Clean Core
entry.content:
SAP Fiori is the business user experience (UX) needed for SAP Business AI and Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP Private.

  1. SAP Fiori is the primary way of bringing SAP Business AI to business users, including SAP’s digital assistant Joule. SAP Fiori is a prerequisite for embedded AI-assisted features and generative AI use cases.
  2. For Clean Core, SAP Fiori brings the SAP Fiori apps and user experience (UX) features needed for clean processes, extensions, and operations that supports your business users and your technical users through continuous innovation – including AI use cases.

Joule diamond icon as it appears in the SAP Fiori launchpad shell bar

In this blog post you will learn why and the minimums you need to get started.

  • Why you need SAP Fiori in SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP Private
  • How SAP Fiori works with Joule for business users
  • Minimum UX to get started with Clean Core
  • Minimum UX to get started with SAP Business AI
  • Learnings to support your UX journey

 

Why you need SAP Fiori in SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP Private

From the beginning of SAP S/4HANA – now over 10 years ago – I have been explaining to SAP customers and partners, that SAP Fiori is how SAP delivers the innovations of SAP S/4HANA to business users.

The innovations of SAP S/4HANA include:

  • On-stack innovations – innovations available within your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition solution.
  • Side-by-side innovations – innovations that extend your solution with cloud services and cloud solutions.

Two (2) top of mind examples of these innovations are:

  • Clean Core processes, extensions, and operations. Many of these are on-stack innovations included in your solution as SAP Fiori apps and launchpad features.
  • SAP Business AI, including Joule – your digital assistant – and other AI use cases embedded with SAP Cloud ERP Private. These are side-by-side innovations that need flexibility, power, and scale of cloud resources to make them cost-effective.

SAP Fiori user experience is now over 12 years old and has matured to cover a vast range of business and technical processes, across many industries.  More than 3.5K apps are already available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. SAP Best Practices (found in the SAP Signavio Process Navigator) highlight the best of these new processes and apps.

SAP Fiori itself continues to innovate to make it easier for business users to work in new ways; on new device types; and caters for a broad range of working conditions and personal needs. For example:

  • My Home for SAP S/4HANA page introduced with SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS01. The AI feature Recommended Apps has been added with SAP S/4HANA 2025,
  • Spaces and pages navigation introduced with SAP S/4HANA 2020 and improved with each SAP S/4HANA release, and
  • Keyboard Shortcuts dialog introduced with SAP S/4HANA 2025 for users who prefer/need keyboard navigation.

My Home for SAP S/4HANA in SAP S/4HANA 2025 showing Recommended Apps tab with recommendations from SAP Business AI

SAP Fiori apps apply consistent floorplans and behaviours that make them quick to learn – as per SAP Design System.  For example, Fiori Elements, Smart Business KPIs, and Review Booklets.  These floorplans are already Clean Core compliant, i.e. they automatically update with the latest improvements as you upgrade your SAP S/4HANA release, feature pack stack and/or SAPUI5 version.  This includes relevant AI-assisted features. Even when you have extended the app, clean core extensions such as Custom Fields and Adapt UI are retained.

Hint: If you need to custom-build your own app, using common floorplans greatly reduces development effort and change management effort.  Start your technical team at the UI5 Demo Kit section Developing Apps with SAP Fiori Elements.  Make sure they look at the Flexible Programming Model Explorer in the Resources section of the UI5 Demo Kit. Get them started with Joule for ABAP.

A major strength of the SAP Fiori launchpad is its ability to launch and easily navigate between SAP Fiori apps and classic UIs (including SAP GUI for HTML, ABAP Web Dynpro applications, WebClient UIs) and URLs. This includes your custom-built apps and (aka “Z”) transactions!

Hint: In workshops I like explain this as the new world of SAP Fiori understands the old world classic UIs and can cater for them.

More than 11.5K classic UIs are pre-configured as ready-to-use launchpad content for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. While Best Practices highlight the best new processes, many quick win apps and features motivate users to move from the classic GUI into a web- and cloud-centric world, such as Search, Share/Bookmark, and Insight Tiles / Insight Cards. 

SAP Business Roles are templates that show how new apps and classic UIs work together to soften the pace of change.  You use the templates as a starting point for your own custom business roles.  By launching all processes from the launchpad, you retain useful classic Uis, combined with new value features, such as personalization, situations, search, embedded analytics, and app-to-app navigation.  For example: app F1873 Manage Sales Orders lets you simplify sales order creation by moving some order types to SAP Fiori and navigate to classic UIs for other order types.

SAP Fiori innovations help business experts and technical teams collaborate to efficiently manage change. It brings no-code/low-code clean core configuration and extension apps, features, and tools to help guide your business users and technical users as you improve your processes over time. For example: SAP Fiori app F1481 Custom Fields to extend end-to-end processes across Fiori apps, classic UIs, analytics, APIs, and much more. 

 

Example of adding Custom Fields to the business context Product General

 

Other important tools and features for managing change include:

  • Adapt UI within apps to control visible/hidden fields/tabs/tables/cards/charts, and provide role-based default settings for filters/tables/charts
  • WYSIWYG editors for launchpad layouts (apps Manage Launchpad Spaces and Manage Launchpad Pages) to communicate recommended/changing tasks for users’ assigned roles
  • Integration with Microsoft Teams for human collaboration
  • Integration with SAP WalkMe for context-sensitive guidance and user behaviour monitoring.

 

Hint: You can provide context-sensitive help via SAP WalkMe as per SAP’s strategic direction. If you have existing SAP Enable Now content, you can continue to use SAP Companion.

For an extended list of configuration and extension apps refer to SAP Fiori for SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Yes you need SAP Fiori to Configure, Adapt and Extend SAP S/4HANA. With SAP S/4HANA 2025, the new app F8438 Manage News for system news is a very welcome addition (think of it as the next generation of transaction SM02).  

Personal note:

  • At customers we are finding the My Home for SAP S/4HANA page motivates business users to move into the launchpad.  Experienced users like having these attractive personalization options to optimize their day.  For suggestions on how to make the most of this personalization refer to: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori – Organizing your My Home page
  • New and time-poor users can be directed to start with the role-based layouts (spaces and pages) via the favorite pages assigned to their role(s). These layouts are easy to configure to reinforce the major processes, activities + on-system tasks of each role.  Layouts can be shared and optionally merged across similar roles.  Layouts respect authorizations by hiding unauthorized tiles, including hiding empty sections and empty pages.  For examples view the SAP Learning video Introducing SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA Cloud [01:33] & further videos in Getting Started with Spaces and Pages. To create your own spaces and pages, refer to SAP Learning video Creating SAP Fiori Launchpad Layouts for Custom Business Roles [11:57]

 

How SAP Fiori works with Joule for business users

Business users authorized for SAP Joule access the Joule web client via the Joule icon on the SAP Fiori launchpad.  The Joule icon appears in the top shell bar of the launchpad – making it always available to business user whether they are in a SAP Fiori app or a classic UI.

 

Joule diamond icon as it appears in the SAP Fiori launchpad shell bar

 

SAP Fiori provides much more than a button to open a dialog window.

Both Joule navigational use cases and transactional use cases rely on the intent-based navigation of SAP Fiori when suggesting users take next steps in a relevant app.

You can find the apps of Joule navigational use cases in SAP Help - SAP Joule - Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition – Finding Apps with Navigational Capability  The apps used in navigational use cases are SAP Fiori apps. The user must be authorized to launch the target app from the launchpad.

Example Joule navigational use case for show sales orders. More details are accessed through the Open button against each Sales Order/Item, navigating to the Manage Sales Order app

Joule transactional use cases enable users to quickly perform tasks in Joule instead of using an app, then optionally navigate to an app to check the result. The user must be authorized to perform the task, and to launch the target app from the launchpad.

Example prompts for transactional use cases with Sales Orders in SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP Private

Hint: Target apps are launched by using SAP Fiori intent-based navigation. The intent is a Semantic Object + Action pair. You can find the matching apps and UIs using the tools of the Fiori Foundation Administrator role. For example: Launchpad App Manager, Launchpad Content Manager Client-Specific, or the read-only tool Launchpad Content Aggregator.

Most embedded AI use cases depend on using SAP Joule, accessing apps via SAP Fiori launchpad, and/or using key user tools in SAP Fiori. You can find the embedded AI use cases listed SAP Note 3558794 - AI Functionality in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

For example, AI-assisted Maintenance Order Recommendations you need:

  • SAP Fiori app F4470 Intelligent Scenario Management to train/activate the underlying AI model
  • SAP Fiori app F4604 Manage Maintenance Notifications and Orders for business users to use the AI

What about your own Joule use case created with SAP Joule Studio? Can you navigate to custom-built SAP Fiori apps or classic UIs for your own use cases? Yes, you can!

By using the intent-based navigation of the SAP Fiori launchpad to navigate to the relevant app or classic UI.  For some ideas on how agentic use cases may work with upcoming Joule Agents refer to High-Impact Use Cases of SAP Joule AI Agents

Minimum UX to get started with Clean Core

To get started with Clean Core, as a minimum you need to:

  • Activate your on-stack (aka local) SAP Fiori launchpad.
  • The activation process by default generates an every-user Fiori Foundation User role for basic launchpad access + a Fiori Foundation Administration role to manage your launchpad content and layouts.

Hint: Check with your ECS team - or take a look in transaction STC02 - as for many customers launchpad activation will already have been done for you. If not, you can activate your launchpad yourself using rapid activation, or you can request your ECS team to do this for you.  

Depending on your starting point, you then need to activate one or more roles and assign these roles to your users, in addition to the every-user Fiori Foundation User role for basic launchpad access.

 

Summary of the 5 Clean Core Principles: Processes, Extensibility, Data, Integration, Operations

For Clean Core Processes, SAP Fiori delivers the SAP Fiori apps and features you will find in Best Practices, along with many other apps that support simpler, more consistent ways of working.

To get started with on-stack Clean Core processes, as a minimum you need to:

  • Activate the SAP Business Role(s) listed in your selected best practices

The rapid activation process creates a copy of the role in the customer namespace ready to refine. Once you have explored the role and the process, you then use the Fiori Foundation Administration role to refine it for your needs.  

For Clean Core Extensibility, SAP Fiori brings to business users (key users) and developers the Level A upgrade-safe, no-code/low-code - aka “key user” - tools you need to extend your business solution rapidly and cleanly. 

Hint: For the full Clean Core extension model refer to: Clean core extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud. For a quick end-to-end on Clean Core references for your team refer to: “Business Excellence with SAP’s New Clean Core Extensibility Levels: Why, What and How”

To get started with on-stack Clean Core extensions, as a minimum you need to:

  • Activate the business role Extensibility Specialist (id SAP_BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC).

Extensibility Specialist page showing the apps assigned

This role is assigned the major key user tools + the Adapt UI feature. You should assign this role to your key users – who may include business experts and your technical team.

To use Adapt UI, your key users will also need access to the app (or app variant) you want them to adapt. 

For further guidance and examples refer to: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – What is Key User Extensibility and Who are your Key Users

Depending on which apps and features you want to start with, you may also need the role Analytics Specialist for key user tools to manage your embedded analytics.  

Hint: The Analytics Specialist role includes the SAP Fiori app F2170 View Browser which provides a quick way to find released CDS Views for clean core extensions and integrations.

Example of the app View Browser in SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS00 showing the app view Released Views for Key Users

For Clean Core Operations, SAP Fiori delivers administration and support tools to help you manage your solution, including your clean core processes and on-stack clean core extensions. For example, SAP Fiori app F1589 Register Extensions for Transport 

Example of app Register Extensions for Transport where key user extensions are assigned to transport requests

To get started with on-stack Clean Core operations, as a minimum you need to:

  • Activate the SAP Business Role Administrator (SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR) 

Hint: If your ECS team have activated your SAP Fiori launchpad for you, they will also have activated the Administrator role.

You should also apply the latest innovations for the App Support launchpad feature and make it available to all your launchpad users.  App Support provides an easy capture of logs, authorization errors, and technical details (app id, UI type, SAPUI5 version, device type, browser OS, etc) directly from the user’s session. You can even authorize your technical team to view/capture errors on behalf of the user.

Refer to:

  • SAP Help – SAP Fiori launchpad - Administration Guide – Setting up App Support
  • SAP blog SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – New improvements in App Support

 

Minimum UX to get started with SAP Business AI

For SAP Business AI, SAP Fiori launchpad provides business users access to SAP Joule, access to navigational and transactional capabilities, plus apps and tools that support embedded AI use cases.

To get started with SAP Joule, a side-by-side innovation, as a minimum you need to:

1. Meet commercial prerequisites

  • Have signed the relevant AI Terms and AI Usage agreements
  • Have subscribed to the cloud services needed for your AI use case

2. In your SAP S/4HANA solution:

  • Activate your on-stack (aka “local”) SAP Fiori launchpad
  • Activate the (SAP or custom) business roles you want to use with AI
  • Assign users to the business roles you want to use with AI

3. In SAP Build Work Zone solution:

  • Activate your unified (aka “central”) SAP Fiori launchpad on SAP Build Work Zone
  • Federate the content of your business roles from SAP S/4HANA to SAP Build Work Zone
  • Federate your user-to-role assignments from SAP S/4HANA to SAP Build Work Zone
  • Activate the Joule icon in your central launchpad and local launchpad

For the quickest way to make this happen refer to Joule provisioning with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition using Cloud Integration Automation service.  This CIAS automates 80% of the setup and guides you through the rest.

If you are new to SAP Build Work Zone and need some background on the architecture and other technical options, refer to Joule - Unified Setup: Bridging Simplicity and Performance.

For understanding your SAP Build Work Zone configuration you can refer to SAP Learning Journey: Setting Up SAP Build Work Zone standard edition and SAP Mobile Start with SAP S/4HANA

Which roles do you need to activate

For Joule navigational and transactional use cases, you will need to activate the roles (SAP Business Roles or equivalent custom roles) you need for your selected line of business (LoB) use cases.

You can find the list of current Joule use cases and their requirements in SAP Note 3523238 - Navigational and Transactional capabilities with Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

For embedded AI use cases:

  • You will need to activate the roles (SAP Business Roles or equivalent custom roles) you need as explained in the use case documentation
  • You may also need to activate the role Analytics Specialist on your local launchpad. This role contains the apps to configure, train, and activate underlying machine learning and generative AI models. For example, app F4469 Intelligent Scenarios.

Hint: If your ECS team have activated your SAP Fiori launchpad for you, they will also have activated the Analytics Specialist role.

Hint: The documentation for each use case in the SAP Business AI discovery center explains which apps are required. 

 

Why 2 launchpads – the local and the central launchpad

The launchpad of SAP Build Work Zone (BWZ) acts a central access point to multiple cloud solutions.  To preserve the maximum functionality of the original solutions, the central launchpad launches apps in the local cloud solution.

SAP Build Work Zone federates the content – i.e. the roles, the layouts, the user assignments – from the local cloud solutions. It can also provide a central access point for federated features such as inbox tasks (SAP Task Center), notifications, searches, and more. These features also navigate to the relevant target app in the local launchpad.

The same is true for SAP Mobile Start which you should think of as the central launchpad on your mobile device, providing an online mobile entry point to apps and features.  Launching an app on a mobile device will reformat the appearance of the app and replace keyboard behaviours with mobile touch equivalents.

The implication is you must have a local launchpad as:

  • A source of launchpad content and layouts
  • A source of user-to-role assignments
  • As a target for launching apps and features.

Which launchpad should your user log into?  Either! It’s your choice. 

Once the prerequisites are met, you can choose to run Joule from the central launchpad or from the local launchpad.  This gives you some flexibility in both change management for users and consumption of services. 

In practice, this will depend on your preferences, subscriptions, and commercial agreements:

  • If all your users are covered under your SAP Build Work Zone subscription, and you are happy for your users to work over the internet, you direct them to the SAP Build Work Zone launchpad.
  • If your subscription only covers a portion of your user base, or you need to restrict internet access, you can split your user base to the 2 launchpads if you wish.

As a rule of thumb, you must activate the central launchpad for AI, mobile, and internet desktop use cases. The more cloud solutions and cloud services you use, the more value you will get from the central launchpad.

Some customers take a tactical approach while they grow scope and skills, by directing users who are primarily desktop/intranet to the local launchpad, while users who are primarily mobile use the central launchpad. 

 

Learnings to get you started

 

If your team is new to SAP Fiori, start with the SAP Learning Journey Learning the Basics of SAP Fiori. To keep your technical team aligned with your User Experience strategy:

  • For launchpad content administrators – SAP Learning video Bringing Apps Onto SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition [05:25] and SAP Learning Journey Designing SAP Build Work Zone
  • For security administrators - SAP Learning Journey:  Exploring the fundamentals of SAP System Security which includes SAP Fiori security and SAP Build Work Zone security.
  • For analytics specialists - SAP Learning Journey: Discovering SAP S/4HANA embedded analytics
  • For administrators: SAP Learning Journeys Implementing and Administering SAP Build Work Zone and Administrating SAP Business Technology Platform and to SAP Learning Journey: Setting Up SAP Build Work Zone standard edition and SAP Mobile Start with SAP S/4HANA

These are complemented by a growing number of short (max 12 minute) learning videos on SAP Learning for optional and self-managed tasks. For example:

  • Introducing SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • Activating SAP Fiori Launchpad Using SAP Fiori Foundation Task List 
  • Bringing Apps Onto SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
  • Configuring the SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA
  • Creating SAP Fiori Launchpad Layouts for Custom Business Roles
  • Adapting the UI of List Report Apps with SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA
  • Patching SAP Fiori (SAPUI5)

You will find supplementary blog posts for deeper dives on our SAP Community  SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA topic page including: 

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Adding a GUI transaction to the launchpad in SAP S/4HANA 2023 or higher
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori – Organizing your My Home page
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori – Navigate with confidence

SAP Activate resources:

  • For how to create your UX Strategy, you will find content and accelerators for UX Adoption. For all UX Adoption content and accelerators select the tag "User Experience" Refer to Run the Establish the Business Value of User Experience Workshop and Define the UX / UI Strategy.
     

Hint: We are currently updating the UX Adoption accelerators for AI, Clean Core, and SAP S/4HANA 2025 based on latest information and running these workshops with many customers worldwide. These updates are planned to be released before the end of 2025. 

  • For getting started with Clean Core you will find the tag Clean Core Success Plan in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP Private roadmaps

SAP Activate roadmaps for SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP Private

Becoming a SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA guru

You’ll find much more on our  SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA topic page

Brought to you by the SAP S/4HANA RIG and Customer Care team

entry.title: How Can Organizations Architect a Scalable Data Engineering Pipeline to Support Real-Time AI-Driven
entry.content:
How Can Organizations Architect a Scalable Data Engineering Pipeline to Support Real-Time AI-Driven Decision Making Across Multiple Domains?

Hello everyone,

I’m working on designing a data engineering pipeline that can support real-time AI analytics across multiple business domains, including marketing, operations, and supply chain. I want to ensure that our architecture is scalable, resilient, and compliant with data privacy regulations.

Specifically, I’m looking for insights on:

Data Ingestion & Streaming: What are the best practices for ingesting large-scale structured and unstructured data in near real-time? Which tools or frameworks are most effective for multi-source streaming pipelines?

Data Storage & Modeling: How can we efficiently store both batch and streaming data while maintaining a single source of truth for AI models? Are there recommended data lake or warehouse strategies?

Feature Engineering for AI: How can feature pipelines be automated and monitored to ensure high-quality inputs for machine learning models without introducing bias?

Real-Time Model Deployment: What architecture patterns (e.g., event-driven, micro-batching, or hybrid) best support real-time AI inference while minimizing latency?

Governance & Compliance: How do organizations ensure data privacy, lineage, and regulatory compliance while enabling agile AI experimentation?

Has anyone implemented a production-ready solution that addresses these challenges? I’d love to hear about architectural choices, tool recommendations, pitfalls, and lessons learned from real-world implementations.

entry.title: Trigger a workflow when a job is scheduled
entry.content:
Hello everyone!

Requirement

Basically I need an ABAP method to be called each time a SAP job is created/scheduled. 
After googling, I found the BOR object "BPJOB" with the event "SCHEDULED". So I thought I could fulfill the requirement by triggering a workflow from this event.

What I have done

I have created the z-class and the workflow. I have successfully tested both.
For the trigger, I identified the BOR-object "BPJOB" with its event "SCHEDULED".
I also checked and rechecked the linkage (transaction SWE2) from the BOR object/event to the workflow. This works, as I can successfully test everything in the transaction SWUE.

The problem

When I now try to schedule a job manually by executing a dummy report in the background, nothing happens. As far as I can tell, the event is not triggered.

This now leads me to believe that I have not understood the functionality of these BOR objects and events correctly. I assumed that the event will be triggered in SAP standard each time a job is scheduled. Is that not the case?

How are these events triggered? Can they only be triggered in z-coding?

What other options do I have to possibly achieve my requirement?

Thank you for your support!
Greeting, Nick

entry.title: Re: Unable to Post Direct Activity Allocation to Event-Ba...
entry.content:
Hi Vero,
Yes, let me explain you more and what you can do achive you want to. Please find below the detail explanation.

SSCUI: Activate Account Assignment to Activity Types
As of version 2508, the SSCUI “Activate Account Assignment to Activity Types” appears to be deprecated or no longer directly accessible via the standard SSCUI catalog. This aligns with SAP’s broader shift toward centralized configuration via CBC (Central Business Configuration) and role-based access to configuration apps. Now you must check if the configuration is now embedded in CBC activity groups or business configuration sets.
Alternatively, verify whether the Controlling Area settings for fiscal year 2025 include the activation of account assignment to activity types. This may now be managed via Manage Your Solution → Configure Your Solution → Controlling → Cost Center Accounting.

G/L Account 55110000 – Blocked for Posting
You're absolutely right that this account may not be explicitly referenced in account determination SSCUIs. However, SAP may still derive it from secondary cost element settings or activity type master data. My suggestions are to check the activity type master data (via “Manage Activity Types”) and see if account 55110000 is assigned as the default cost element. Review the cost element category for 55110000 — if it’s set as a secondary cost element for internal activity allocation, it may be automatically picked up. Also check CO version settings and plan/actual integration — sometimes blocked accounts are referenced indirectly through planning profiles.

WBS Element Configuration
It sounds like your WBS element setup is solid. Since it’s released and assigned to an investment profile that allows internal activity allocation, the issue likely lies elsewhere — possibly in how the system interprets event-based logic during posting.

Use of F3697A in Event-Based Projects
You're absolutely correct — SAP Help Portal explicitly lists Manage Direct Activity Allocation (F3697A) as a supported app for event-based investment projects. However, SAP Community reports suggest that certain combinations of cost elements, activity types, or fiscal year settings may still cause issues.


Today the app is supported, but only under specific conditions — including proper activation of account assignment, unblocked cost elements, and compatible fiscal year settings. If the fiscal year 2025 is not activated for account assignment in CO area A000, the system will reject the posting even if everything else is correct.


Here is what i recommended steps for you,
Check Fiscal Year Settings:
Use CBC or configuration apps to confirm that account assignment to activity types is active for 2025 in CO area A000.

Review Activity Type Master Data:
Confirm that the correct secondary cost element is assigned and that it’s not blocked.

Explore CBC or Raise an SAP Incident:
If you cannot locate the SSCUI or CBC activity, consider raising a support ticket to confirm whether the configuration has been migrated or renamed.

Hope the above explanation is okay with you.

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Pune 2025 — A Celebration of Ideas, Energy, and Collaboration
entry.content:
Once again, the SAP community in Pune showed its strength, passion, and drive. On 11th October 2025, SAP Inside Track Pune returned for its second edition — and it was nothing short of spectacular.

A Community Reunion

From the moment doors opened, the buzz in the air made it clear: this wasn’t just an event — it was a community coming together. Over 200+ enthusiastic participants, 20+ speakers, and a dedicated team of volunteers gathered at SAP Labs India, ITPP, Pune to learn, share, and grow. The energy, camaraderie, and excitement were palpable.

🤝 Voices That Inspire

We kicked off with an inspiring keynote by Saicharan Krishnamoorthy, tracing the journey of SAP Inside Track and spotlighting how far Pune has come on its SAP path. The stories shared, insights revealed, and vision laid out set a vibrant tone for the day.

The main stage was beautifully hosted by Punith Oswal (@Punith_Oswal), SAP Champion and member of the SIT core team. His energy and expertise set the perfect tone for the day’s sessions.

A Day of Deep Dive Learning

This year’s focus — Business AI in SAP — resonated through every session and conversation. From AI Strategy to Embedded AI, SAP BTP, modernization, and partner innovations, speakers took us on a rich journey of possibilities. Every talk, every case study, and every Q&A added layers of real-world relevance, innovation, and practical wisdom.

Sessions and Tracks

The event featured a variety of sessions divided across four different tracks, allowing attendees to dive deep into the topics that piqued their interest. Each session was packed with invaluable insights and the latest trends in the SAP ecosystem:

Gratitude to Our Pillars

Events like this don’t happen on their own. A heartfelt thank you to:

Our Esteemed Partners: Amazon Web Services, Rojo Integrations B.V , Mindset Consulting LLC,  Primus TechSystems, SAP Press - Your support and belief made this event a great success!

Our speakers, for generously sharing your stories, expertise, and bold ideas.

Our core team and volunteers, who poured time, energy, and love into every detail — from logistics to hello smiles.

A huge shout-out to Saicharan Krishnamoorthy (@saicharank ) and Devprasad Kambli (@Devkambli) for leading the team from the front, your efforts went above and beyond to make sure everything came together flawlessly!

Unforgettable Moments and Key Takeaways

One of the standout aspects of SAP Inside Track Pune 2025 was witnessing the sheer enthusiasm and energy of Pune’s vibrant tech community. Professionals, learners, and SAP enthusiasts from across India came together to share knowledge, exchange ideas, and explore the latest innovations in the SAP ecosystem — creating an atmosphere that was truly inspiring. The presence of participants who travelled from cities like Bangalore, Hyderabad, and Mumbai added incredible diversity and a sense of unity to the event.

Beyond the sessions and keynotes, the event was filled with opportunities to connect, collaborate, and build lasting relationships. Participants engaged with peers, SAP experts, and thought leaders — sparking discussions that could lead to new collaborations, innovative solutions, and enhanced skills across SAP technologies and integration.

SIT Pune 2025 was more than just an event; it was a celebration of community, curiosity, and collaboration. Everyone — from attendees to speakers, volunteers, and partners — walked away with valuable insights and experiences, contributing to something truly special in Pune’s SAP ecosystem.

Looking Ahead

Reflecting on the success of SIT Pune 2025, the excitement for the future is palpable. Pune has firmly established itself on the SAP map, and this is just the beginning. The energy, passion, and ideas shared during this event have laid a strong foundation for even bigger opportunities, collaborations, and innovations in the years ahead.

Let’s keep the momentum going! If you couldn’t attend, make sure to follow our SAP Inside Track Pune pages on LinkedIn and join the SAP Pune Community group for updates, future events, and exclusive content.

The future of SAP in Pune is brighter than ever — and we’re only getting started! 

A heartfelt thank you to everyone who made SIT Pune 2025 such a tremendous success. Here’s to many more milestones, learning, and moments of inspiration for the SAP community in Pune and beyond.

 

Until Next Time....

Cheers!

SAP Community Pune - Core Team

entry.title: Re: MRN2 transaction adding +1 devaluation indicator on e...
entry.content:
Hi Vishal,
As you explain the behavior described in the MRN2 transaction—where it adds +1 to the devaluation indicator on each run regardless of the last goods receipt year—is a known issue when the configuration or logic doesn't properly account for the material's movement history. This is expected behavior of MRN2 should evaluate the last goods receipt year and assign a devaluation indicator based on the configured time frames (e.g., 1 year, 2 years, etc.). This is actual behavior to increments the devaluation indicator by +1 each time it's run, ignoring the actual last goods receipt date.

The root cause is if this typically occurs when the system isn't correctly referencing the last goods receipt year during the MRN2 run. Instead, it applies a default progression logic.
SAP Note 691022 discusses this issue and suggests that the standard module may lack sufficient interface parameters to handle split valuation or materials without recent movements

To fix this one my recommendation is to write User Exit EXIT_SAPLNIW1_002, Implement or enhance this user exit to include logic that checks the last goods receipt year and maps it to the correct devaluation indicator.
You may need to extend the interface with parameters like I_BWTAR and I_OLD_ABWKZ to handle valuation types and previous indicators.

Custom Development: If standard functionality is insufficient, consider a custom enhancement that, Retrieves the last goods receipt date. Maps it to the correct time frame (e.g., 0–1 year, 1–2 years). Assigns the corresponding devaluation indicator and percentage.

Please check the configuration by reviewing your devaluation indicator configuration in customization ensure each indicator is correctly mapped to a time frame. Validate that the logic used in MRN2 references these mappings dynamically rather than incrementally.

Hope above solution might work for you

You can visit this url and get some related information might help you. https://www.stechno.net/repository/sap-notes.html?id=691022#gsc.tab=0

entry.title: Add your own App Info section to App Support (SAP S/4HANA 2025)
entry.content:
App Support already lets you enhance menu and submenu structures with customer-specific information (see my previous post for an example). With SAP S/4HANA 2025, there is now an official enhancement point for the first view of App Support as well. That means you can add your own App Info section with minimal effort—for example to show support contacts, usage notes, or system-specific hints right where users need them.

Result of enhancement

What you’ll build

  • A new App Info section called “Hello World Example”
  • Two example entries for your new section

Good to know before you start

  • Available with SAP S/4HANA 2025 (uses a new enhancement location).
  • Implemented via BAdI /UI2/ADE_APP_INFO_PROVIDER inside Enhancement Spot /UI2/ADE_DATASOURCE.

Since the App Support plugin is a freestyle app it can only be enhanced in a customer project, or via the predefined extension points. In S/4 HANA 2025 a new enhancement location was introduced, therefore it is now also possible to enhance the first view, with relative little effort. 

 

Step-by-step implementation

In your development system navigate to Enhancement Spot /UI2/ADE_DATASOURCE in transaction SE80.

Step 1: Navigate to Enhancement Spot /UI2/ADE_DATASOURCE

 

In this enhancement spot choose /UI2/ADE_APP_INFO_PROVIDER, which is the BAdI Definition we'll use for the enhancement. 

Step 2: Create a BAdI Implementation for definition /UI2/ADE_APP_INFO_PROVIDER

 

First you will receive a list of already existing Enhancement Implementations. Each implementation represents a data source for the App Support plugin. For our purpose we want to create a new implementation in customer namespace.

Step 3: Create a new BadI Implementation from the overview

 

In the follow up popup enter a meaningful name for your Enhancement implementation. For this example I'm naming it ZBADI_CUSTOMER_INFO.

Step 4: Provide a name and description for your Enhancement Implementation

 

Confirm the name of the implementation and then another popup opens for the BAdI Implementation. Provide your preferred BAdI Implementation name (I simply used the same as for the Enhancement Implementation). More importantly add a name for the new Implementing class. I used ZCL_BADI_CUSTOMER_INFO.

Step 5: Create a BAdI Implementation and Implementing Class

 

You should now have a complete Enhancement Implementation with BAdI Implementation and Implementing class. Activate your changes and ensure the implementation is also flagged as active.

Step 6: Observe the created objects in your Enhancement Implementation

 

If everything is in order, we can now create a new Filter Value for the implementation. This is important, since this value is used to uniquely identify the new data provider in App Support.

Step 7: Navigate to the Filter Values

 

In the Filter Value area create a new Combination, then edit the new Combination directly to add your unique value.

Step 8: Create a new Combination and edit the Filter Value

 

Enter a unique value for the filter value APPINFORMATIONGROUPID.  This value will represent the type of data you want to display in the App Info section of App Support. In this example I use ZCUSTOMERINFO.

Step 9: Enter a unique value for your enhancement 

 

From a enhancement framework perspective we are now good to go. We can now start to work on the actual implementation logic of the customer enhancement in the implementing class of our BAdI.

Step 10: Navigate to the Implementing class of your enhancement

 

Navigate to the ABAP class editor, either in ABAP Development Tools, or directly here in SE80. I'll use SE80 for this example, but of course ADT can be used instead.

Step 11: Open the ABAP class editor for your Implementing Class

 

Since we're in an object oriented environment, it makes sense to inherit some basic attributes from the main App Support data source class.  Therefore navigate to tab Properties and then press button Superclass. 

Step 12 (optional): Navigate to tab Properties and press button Superclass

 

Enter superclass /UI2/CL_ADE_BADI_BASE to make use of the inheritance model in App Support. You can then reuse the authorization check method of the superclass. 

Step 13 (optional): Enter superclass /UI2/CL_ADE_BADI_BASE

 

Now let's get to the implementation logic of our enhancement. Navigate to the Method overview and observe the 3 new methods that need to be implemented from the interface /UI2/IF_ADE_BADI_APP_INFO_PROV. We want to start with the method VERIFY_SOURCE_AVAILABLE to ensure our BAdI is being processed. 

Step 14: Navigate to tab Methods and doubleclick method VERIFY_SOURCE_AVAILABLE

 

This method allows you a dynamic control of your implementation. As input we receive IS_KEYS, which uniquely identifies the currently displayed app, from where App Support is being called. In addition you receive the activity (03=Display, DL= Download). It would be possible to check the availability based on IS_KEYS-APPKEY or base on a customer specific authorization value. Our filter value ZCUSTOMERINFO is added automatically to authorization field SUI_ADEDS of authorization object S_FLP_AS. This could then be used for an authorization check in our class. In this example we keep it simple and always enable our datasource.

Step 15: Enter this code to make sure the BAdI is always executed

 

Here is the code snippet from above:

    "always available or dependent on is_keys
    rv_source_available = /ui2/if_ade_badi_data_provider=>sc_status_available.

Make sure to use the interface attribute sc_status_available('01') and not abap_true('X').

Next navigate to method GET_APP_INFO_GROUP and create a code implementation there. It is important to return the appkey and the groupid. The groupid is the filter value that we entered for our BAdI. This uniquely identifies the source of the provided data. Without the correct value, the data can't be mapped correctly in App Support.

The groupname attribute will be used as section heading in the App Info page.

Step 16: Enter the group information you want to display.

 

Here is the code snippet from above:

    DATA: ls_group TYPE /UI2/ADE_s_APP_INFO_GROUP.

    LOOP AT it_appkey_range ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_key>).
      ls_group-appkey = <ls_key>-low.
      ls_group-groupid = 'ZCUSTOMERINFO'. "same as filter value in BAdI implementation
      ls_group-groupname = 'Hello World Example'.
      APPEND ls_group TO ct_app_info_ext.
    ENDLOOP.

Now we're almost there, only one more method to implement to display our data. Navigate to the final method GET_APP_INFO_GROUP_VALUE. As the name suggests, we can add name value pairs to the new group we defined in GET_APP_INFO_GROUP.

Step 17: Implement method GET_APP_INFO_GROUP_VALUE for your data

 

Here is the code snippet from above:

    DATA: ls_info TYPE /ui2/ade_s_app_info_group_val.
    "for requested apps provide the info extension
    LOOP AT it_appkey_range ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_key>).
      ls_info-appkey = <ls_key>-low.
      ls_info-groupid = 'ZCUSTOMERINFO'. "again add the filter value of the BAdI
      ls_info-valuename = 'Further information on our customer app'.
      ls_info-value     = 'Please do not enter multiple values for the filters at once.'.
      APPEND ls_info TO ct_app_info_ext_val.
      ls_info-valuename = 'Contact Person'.
      ls_info-value     = 'john.doe@customercompany.com'.
      APPEND ls_info TO ct_app_info_ext_val.
    ENDLOOP.

Finally save and activate your changes in your class. After activation check your implementation in an app of your choice and open App Support from there. You should be able to see your enhancemed section right away.

Step 18: Check your enhancement in App Support

 

Tips and troubleshooting

Nothing shows up:

  • Verify that VERIFY_SOURCE_AVAILABLE returns sc_status_available.
  • Confirm your groupid in both GET_APP_INFO_GROUP and GET_APP_INFO_GROUP_VALUE exactly matches the BAdI filter value (e.g., ZCUSTOMERINFO).
  • Ensure all objects and the BAdI implementation are active.

Wrong section title:

  • Adjust ls_group-groupname in GET_APP_INFO_GROUP.

Authorization control:

  • If you need to restrict visibility, use S_FLP_AS and field SUI_ADEDS = your Group ID in VERIFY_SOURCE_AVAILABLE (or call the superclass authorization method if you inherited /UI2/CL_ADE_BADI_BASE).

 Transport:

  • Create all artifacts in the customer namespace (Z* or Y*) and add them to a transport as usual.

 Performance:

  • Keep your GET_* methods lightweight. If you read from the database, do it efficiently and only for the keys in it_appkey_range.

 

Wrap-up

With the new enhancement option in SAP S/4HANA 2025, adding helpful, context-specific information to the first view of App Support is straightforward. Use your own Group ID to define a section, then supply clean name-value pairs to guide users with tips, constraints, and contact details—right where they look for help.

For Questions and Answers on SAP Fiori – please see the SAP Community Q&A area and feel free to post your own questions.
I hope you find this blog post helpful – feel free to leave comments and feedback, you can follow the SAP Fiori Launchpad tag to receive updates on blog posts here.

entry.title: New App Support Features in S/4 HANA 2025
entry.content:
If you support SAP Fiori, you know how valuable App Support for the SAP Fiori launchpad can be for getting the right technical context quickly. With the latest update, the app adds three highly requested capabilities that reduce back‑and‑forth and help you pinpoint issues faster:

  1. Display of target mapping parameters
  2. A new enhancement location to show your own customer support information
  3. UI5 error logs and version information

Below is a practical overview of what changed, why it matters, and how to use it.

What’s new at a glance

See the exact target mapping parameters resolved for the current intent, including defaults and any parameters passed by navigation.
Capture UI5 error logs directly from the end‑user session and quickly review the SAPUI5 version and loaded libraries.
Provide your own support contact details and links inside the App Support experience using a new enhancement location designed for customer content.


Display of target mapping parameters

What it is:

You can now see the full set of parameters tied to the target mapping of the app you are analyzing. This includes parameters defined in the target mapping, their current values (after intent resolution), and any parameters that were supplied during navigation.

Why it helps:

Clarify why an app opens with a specific filter or variant.
Check whether required parameters are missing or mismatched.
Validate if defaults from the target mapping are being applied as expected.


How to use it:

Enable authorization ADEAPPINFOTMPARAMETERS in field SUI_ADEDS for authorization object S_FLP_AS.  Then open App Support from the same SAP Fiori launchpad session where you experience an issue.

In the App Overview section you will see the new  section Target Mapping Parameters. Compare the resolved values against the expected configuration in your content manager or against the parameters in the URL or tile configuration.
If troubleshooting, capture a screenshot or copy the parameters to include in your ticket, along with the business role/catalog and the semantic object/action.


Tips:

Reproduce the issue first, then open App Support so that the parameters reflect the current user journey.
If multiple target mappings could match the intent, use the list to verify which one was actually selected.

 

New enhancement location for customer information

What it is:

There is a new enhancement location specifically intended for customer content inside App Support. This lets you display your organization’s support contacts, service hours, and any guidance you want end users to see when they open App Support.

Why it helps:

  • Put “how to get help” in front of users at the moment they need it.
  • Standardize internal support instructions across apps and roles.
  • Reduce time spent hunting for the right hotline or ticket queue.


How to use it:

Please read my other post on how to implement the enhancement in more detail, following this link:
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/add-your-own-app-info-section-to-app-support-sap-s-4hana-2025/ba-p/14238020

 


UI5 error logs and version information

What it is:

Even though this feature was released in S/4 HANA 2023 I want to mention it here as well. App Support now surfaces UI5 logs captured from the current session, alongside SAPUI5 and FLP version information and loaded libraries. You get a consolidated view similar to what a developer might extract from the browser console, without asking an end user to run developer tools.

Why it helps:

Quickly identify JavaScript errors and warnings raised by the app or shell. Confirm the SAPUI5 version and build level in use on the client. Understand which UI5 libraries and themes are loaded when the issue occurs.


How to use it:

With the problematic app open (or after reproducing the issue), launch App Support in the same session.

Open the UI5 logs and version section. Filter by errors, warnings, or info as needed.
Use the copy/export function to attach logs and version details to your support ticket.

Tips:

If possible, avoid refreshing before opening App Support so the logs include the exact sequence of events leading to the error.
Combine UI5 logs with the target mapping parameters to give a complete picture to your support team or SAP.

Wrap-up

The features described are available with the latest delivery of App Support for the SAP Fiori launchpad. Exact availability depends on your ABAP platform and SAPUI5 release. Refer to the SAP Help documentation for your system version.
No special browser setup is needed to capture UI5 logs via App Support; the app operates within the user’s launchpad session.

For Questions and Answers on SAP Fiori – please see the SAP Community Q&A area and feel free to post your own questions.
I hope you find this blog post helpful – feel free to leave comments and feedback, you can follow the SAP Fiori Launchpad tag to receive updates on blog posts here.

entry.title: New "Responsible" Document Attribute & Enhanced Notification Features
entry.content:
New Document Attribute: “Responsible”

A new optional document attribute called "Responsible" is now available under the Additional Information tab in your document editor.

Purpose: The "Responsible" field is intended to designate the person accountable for the document, separate from the Owner, who may be the document creator or administrator.

Validation Rule: The Responsible and Owner must be different users. Assigning the same person to both roles will result in an error message.

Expanded Document Notification Types

To keep you better informed about document updates, we've added three new types of user notifications for anyone authorized to edit documents:

  1. Documents: assigned to you
  2. Documents: status changed
  3. Documents: content changed

These notifications help users stay on top of important changes in shared documentation.

When Notifications Are Triggered:

Event

Notified Users

Details

Status Change

Owner & Responsible

Triggered when document status changes.

Content Change

Owner & Responsible

Triggered when internal document content or external file is updated.

Assignee Change

Owner & Responsible

Triggered when Owner or Responsible changes.

Approval Started

Other role(s) in approval procedure

Informs reviewers that the document needs attention.

Note: The user who made the change will not receive a notification, as they are already aware of the action taken.

Email vs. In-App Notifications

  • If email notifications are enabled, users will receive a detailed email containing:
    • What changed (status, content, assignee, etc.)
    • A direct link to the document
  • If only in-app notifications are enabled:
    • Users will see a notification with the change type and a link to the document

entry.title: Re: Stop using Mail Package! © - Simplify your mail receiver adapter scenarios
entry.content:
For anyone trying this out with an FTP -> Mail instead of SFTP -> Mail, the Mail adapter will not properly set the filename.

There is probably a workaround, but if you find yourself frustrated with email attachments called "MainDocument.xml" or "ATT00001.xml", my honest suggestion is to avoid using the FTP adapter, and do whatever you have to do to use SFTP instead.

I figure the reason is that the Mail adapter looks for the attribute parameter ("http://sap.com/xi/XI/System", "FileName), while the FTP adapter does not set this like the SFTP adapter, but instead sets ("http://sap.com/xi/XI/System/File", "FileName").

Why SAP did not make the Mail adapter to check both of these when deciding the filename? Your guess is as good as mine...

entry.title: New tutorial for UI5 Middleware FE Mockserver
entry.content:
A new hands-on tutorial is now available to accompany the Devtoberfest session UI5 Middleware FE Mockserver in Practice — Setup, Use Cases, Live Coding. It’s a guided, step-by-step journey showing how to use @sap-ux/ui5-middleware-fe-mockserver productively with Fiori Elements and beyond covering setup, data strategies, actions, multi-service scenarios, tenant isolation, offline E2E testing with wdi5, and recording real backend traffic for offline replay.

Why this tutorial matters

The mockserver lets you develop and test Fiori apps locally and offline with metadata-accurate data, predictable scenarios, and action implementations without waiting on backend availability. The tutorial distills best practices into small exercises you can run immediately.

What you’ll learn (exercise overview)

ExerciseFocusKey Takeaways
1. Basic Setup – Generated DataZero-config mock data from metadataStart fast; remove backend proxy for true offline; draft simulation
2. Custom JSON DataPredictable datasetsStable testing scenarios; relationships; consistent IDs and referential keys
3. JavaScript LogicDynamic data + actionsImplement getInitialDataSet and executeAction; validations; latency simulation
4. Multiple ServicesBookshop + ReviewsMicroservices-style config with distinct metadata and datasets
5. Cross-Service CommunicationService-to-service flowsTrigger operations across services (e.g., promotion creates review)
6. Context-Based IsolationTenant-specific dataUse ?sap-client= to switch tenants; optional tenant-aware logic
7. Error HandlingBusiness and system errorsReturn 400/404/422/500/501 with helpful messages for UI testing
8. Offline E2E Testingwdi5 + mockserverReliable CI-ready tests without backend dependency
9. Record Live ODataui5-middleware-odata-recorderCapture real backend traffic → generate mock datasets for offline replay

How to get started

The tutorial is available in the README and is designed to run locally in small, focused apps per exercise. You’ll find commands, file locations, and ready-to-run configurations.

  • Tutorial (GitHub README): ui5-fe-mockserver-tutorial
  • Open UX OData repository: github.com/SAP/open-ux-odata  |  Docs: API & guides
  • Mockserver API references: getInitialDataSet  |  base API
  • OData traffic recorder: ui5-middleware-odata-recorder  |  documentation
  • Generate a Fiori Elements app (optional): Create App with Fiori Tools  |  EasyUI5 Generator

Session context

This tutorial was introduced in the Devtoberfest session UI5 Middleware FE Mockserver in Practice — Setup, Use Cases, Live Coding, featuring live coding around configuration, data providers, offline mode, tenant-specific datasets with fallbacks, cross-service scenarios, and wdi5 integration for robust E2E tests. You can rewatch the session now.

Links

  • Devtoberfest event page: Session details
  • Devtoberfest event: YouTube Live Stream
  • Tutorial (GitHub README): ui5-fe-mockserver-tutorial
  • Open UX OData repo & docs: Repository  |  Documentation
  • Recorder middleware: GitHub  |  README

entry.title: Re: Win-Win-Win Situation: How SAP Customers and Partners can connect with the Academia
entry.content:
Inspiring post, Isadora! It really captures the "Win-Win-Win" synergy of the SAP University Alliances program. Fostering talent, sharing knowledge, and driving innovation is what's needed to prepare the next generation of (SAP) professionals.

Highlighting some of the highly effective ways I've seen this academia-meets-industry collaboration truly flourish:

Connecting at SAP UA Academic Conferences: Natural meeting points where industry professionals presenting case studies, expressing talent needs, and participating in panel duscussions are powerful ways to bridge practice and education.

Utilizing the established network of SAP UA Faculty Coordinators to officially disseminate internship and job opportunities ensures that the information reaches the most qualified, skilled students directly and efficiently. This formalizes the talent pipeline and creates a clear pathway from the classroom to a career.

Joint events: Collaborating with SAP clubs and student associations on campus, such as hosting "Tech Talk" evenings or career panels, makes the industry tangible and accessible to students right where they are.

Motivational in-class visits: A dynamic in-class visit from an industry leader can transform a theoretical lesson into a practical, career-shaping moment for students.

Co-coaching at ERPsim challenges and competitions: Having co-coaches from SAP customers or partners work alongside faculty to mentor student teams provides unparalleled, real-time business strategy training and immediate industry exposure for students.

These are some of the activities which translate into concrete, measurable impact initiatives to ensure the academic curriculum remains relevant and industry-ready.

A question for the community:
What is the most impactful way SAP customers could start engaging with academia today to see the quickest return on investment in talent?

entry.title: Re: Miro enhancement
entry.content:
To fulfill your FI requirement—automatically transferring the Contract Number (EKKO-KONNR) from the Purchase Order (PO) into the invoice line item field (BSEG-VERTN) during MIRO/MIR7—you’ll need to implement an enhancement that bridges MM and FI data during invoice posting. This enables F110 to consolidate payments by contract using BSEG-VERTN and the BP Regrouping Key.

You can try with BAdI MM_IV_LINE_ITEM, method PROCESS_ITEM. This BAdI is triggered during invoice posting and allows modification of line item data before FI document creation. Implementation Logic:

  • Read the PO number from the invoice item (RBKP/RBEP).
  • Use EKKO to fetch KONNR (contract number).
  • Assign KONNR to BSEG-VERTN.

entry.title: App Support - App Inspector now available from the Fiori Launchpad Home
entry.content:
If you support SAP Fiori users, you know the drill: a user reports “my app doesn’t open,” but your technical user doesn’t have that business role, or you’re on the Home screen wondering where to start. With the latest version of S/4 HANA 2025, you can launch App Inspector directly from the Fiori Launchpad Home via the familiar App Support entry – and immediately browse a complete catalog of all applications available in the system, regardless of your assigned roles.

This builds on the App Support for SAP Fiori Launchpad capability described in the previous blog, and extends it with a system-wide catalog and more powerful search so supporters can find and troubleshoot any app faster.

What’s new

  • Same entry point, now usable from the Home screen Open the user menu on the Fiori Launchpad Home and choose App Support. No need to launch a specific app first.

  • Complete catalog of all apps in the system Browse everything available in the system, independent of your role assignments. Ideal for technical triage and landscape visibility.

  • More technical information for in-house support Quickly see technical identifiers and configuration details useful for troubleshooting (for example: Fiori app ID, component, intent, target mapping source, system alias, OData service, and more within App Inspector).

  • Powerful search Find apps by user, Fiori ID, Role, or Catalog ID. This helps you locate exactly the app a business user is referring to, even if you don’t have the same role assignment.

Access App Support - App Inspector through the Fiori Launchpad Home Screen

 

How it works

  1. From the Fiori Launchpad Home, open the user menu and select App Support.
  2. The App Support catalog view opens, listing all applications available in the system.
  3. Use search to locate an app:
    • By user: enter a user to see apps available for them.
    • By Fiori ID: use the SAP Fiori app ID you received in a ticket (for example, F1234).
    • By Role: search by a PFCG role name.
    • By Catalog ID: search by Fiori Launchpad catalog ID to review content organization.
  4. Select an application to open details. From there, launch App Inspector to analyze technical configuration and resolve issues such as:
    • Intent resolution and target mapping
    • Component and application version
    • System alias and destination
    • OData service bindings and backend availability
  5. Use deep links to open the app or share a link with colleagues. Capture findings and next steps directly from the Inspector view.

 

 

App Inspector list with filter options

Typical support scenarios this streamlines

  • A user reports an issue with a specific Fiori app ID. Search by Fiori ID, open the app details, and run App Inspector to verify configuration, intent, target mapping, and backend connectivity.

  • A supporter needs to confirm whether an app is present in the system and how it is exposed. Use the catalog and role or catalog search to see availability and assignments, even without business roles.

  • Triage “I can’t find my app” tickets. Search by user to compare what the user should see against catalog contents and identify role/catalog gaps.

  • Validate transports or configuration changes. Use App Inspector to check app versions and content source.

Detail view of an app in App Inspector

Availability and prerequisites

  • Entry point: App Support in the user menu on the Fiori Launchpad Home screen.
  • Feature set: App Inspector uses the same base as App Support and provides the technical analysis views described in the SAP Help.
  • Prerequisites: Ensure App Support and App Inspector are available and configured in your ABAP system. Appropriate authorizations are required to access support tooling and system-wide catalog content. For setup and configuration, refer to the SAP Help documentation:  https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_NEW/a7b390faab1140c087b8926571e942b7/94d8f974fcda459ea35dedd00c846603.html

Tips for adoption

  • Add App Support to your standard operating procedures for first-line Fiori triage.
  • Train supporters on search strategies (by user, Fiori ID, role, catalog) to shorten time-to-resolution.
  • Use App Inspector findings to create clear handoffs between frontend and backend teams.
  • Consider periodic catalog reviews to detect content inconsistencies across roles and catalogs.

What stays consistent

  • You still access App Support via the same user menu entry. The difference is that you can now start from the Home screen and immediately leverage the catalog without opening a specific app.

We’d love your feedback

Tell us how the catalog view and App Inspector help your support process. Which searches do you use most? What additional technical details would speed up your troubleshooting activities even more?

Further reading

  • App Support for the SAP Fiori Launchpad (previous blog): https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/app-support-for-the-sap-fiori-launchpad/ba-p/13487591
  • App Inspector documentation: https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_NEW/a7b390faab1140c087b8926571e942b7/9306ad5bca61445089f1c901196b8135.html

With App Support now accessible from the Fiori Launchpad Home and a complete application catalog at your fingertips, supporters can locate, inspect, and resolve issues faster—without the overhead of business role assignments.

entry.title: SAP CodeJam HANA ML in Porto 2025-09 Recap
entry.content:
At the end of September, we held an SAP CodeJam event in Vila Nova de Gaia, Portugal. The event focused on exploring the foundations of AI applications with the SAP HANA Cloud: Vector Engine and Knowledge Graph Engine.

Thanks to the local host and organizers: @MatheusBrasil , @MRobalinho and the rest of the team...

...and participants!

It was great to have my teammate and fellow developer advocate @qmacro joining us... not only during the lunch break 🐟

 

SAP CodeJam in Porto was the day before the very first SAP Inside Track there, so it was great to share a drink during a Stammtisch after the CodeJam...

 The following day, I had a chance to present the long story of LLM auto completion to AI agents—we went in just three years! And invited everyone to join SAP TechEd to watch our Developer Keynote.

November is going to be an intensive month with SAP TechEd on Tour in Berlin, Sydney, and Bengaluru, followed by SAP CodeJams in Melbourne, Singapore, and the Middle East.

I always take the opportunity to experience at least a little bit of the city I am in, so you can see my photos: https://www.instagram.com/p/DPyfRcMDKko/?img_index=1

Would you like to host such an SAP CodeJam?

entry.title: Re: 在进行应收汇票的批量认领导入时，提示抵销科目的问题，提示未在公司代码中定义，请指教下，如何处理的
entry.content:
Hello @lemon-xue ,

Thank you for your question and follow-up

The error shows that Offsetting Account Determination is not active for your company's BoE receivable acceptance. In Public Cloud, setup explicitly includes defining versions for Offsetting Account Determination as part of the BoE configuration.  SAP Help Portal-Bill of Exchange Process Overview (CN)

Refer to below SAP KBA documentation below for possible solutions

3019897 – The Offsetting account cannot be determined in the document
It explains why the system cannot find an offsetting account and guides you to the necessary setup, including using Determine Offsetting Accounts Manually – China when automatic determination is not yet configured. SAP Support Portal-3019897 - Offsetting account cannot be determined in document&1&2&3

If you still encounter issues after setup or manual pairing, these two KBAs will assist with troubleshooting.

3461513 – How to manually determine offsetting accounts (step-by-step for the China apps). SAP Support Portal-3461513 - How to manually determine the offsetting accounts?

3461466 – After manual determination, the journal entry is still not in the cash flow (what you should check next). SAP Support Portal-3461466 - After manually determining the offsetting accounts, the journal entry still did not appear in the cash flow statements

For configuration, including activating and maintaining versions and rules, see SAP Help Configuring Offsetting Account Determination. SAP Help-Configuring Offsetting Account Determination

如需中文翻译或进一步支持，请随时告诉我。此致，敬礼

Chuma
